Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of the border wall on crime rates in El Paso, stating that it immediately transformed the city into one of the safest in the country.
Understate: The claim understates the safety of El Paso before the construction of the wall, suggesting that it had extremely high rates of violent crime when it actually had a relatively low crime rate compared to other cities.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that the border wall was the sole or primary cause of the decrease in crime rates in El Paso.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes a direct and causal relationship between the construction of the wall and the decrease in crime rates, without considering other factors or potential alternative explanations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that El Paso was not one of the most dangerous cities in the country before the construction of the wall, as it had a low violent crime rate compared to other cities.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider other possible explanations for the decrease in crime rates in El Paso, such as broader national trends in crime reduction or local law enforcement efforts.
